text: - My goal is to seek to empower

as many people as I
can through technology.
And really try to be as ethical

and responsible as I
can be as an engineer.
My name is Gedeon Baende and I'm an AWS AI
and ML Scholarship student,
and I'm studying integrated engineering at
the University of San Diego.
(gentle ethereal music)
(waves crashing)

- Hello.
- Hi.

- I'm from Himachal Pradesh, India.

- I'm interested in
artificial intelligence.
- If they can do it, then I can do it too.
(waves crashing)
(gentle music)

- [Gedeon] I was born in the
Democratic Republic of Congo,
in Kinshasa.
When I was 13 years old, my parents

made the difficult decision
to send my siblings
and I to live with my aunt in the US
in search of a better education.
One thing led to the other and then bam,
just like that, we're in Utah.
Now I didn't know any English.

All of a sudden, I'm here
where I can't speak to anyone.
I can't understand what they're saying.
And I have to go and learn the language

as fast as I can and then
figure out a way to fit in.
(gentle serene music)
My aunt was always pushing us.

I mean, she did a really
good job by making sure
that we were doing very well in school.
That really helped me grow into
a more confident version of myself.
Really helping me see that I was capable

of achieving whatever
it was I put my mind to.

I'm really driven to
giving back to my family
for all their sacrifice over the years

for me to be able to
get to where I am today.
(gentle serene music)
My intro to computer science,
it was brutal, if I'm being honest.
(elevator door dinging)
I started having doubts and thinking that

I wasn't as bright as some
of the other students.
But I actually wanted to code.
I see artificial intelligence being part
of society in so many ways.
That's when I discovered the AWS AI
and ML Scholarship program.

That exposure to the course
and everything I learned,
especially for neural networks.

I was able to directly apply
it to my capstone project.
(indistinct murmuring)
(gentle lilting music)
We've estimated that by 2030,

60 million EV batteries are
gonna end up in the landfills.

That's a lot of unused
energy that's going to waste.
Our project aims to use software that
non-invasively diagnoses the EV batteries,
and provides potential use cases
for second-life applications.
Such as appliances or for energy storage.

We wanna make use of all
of that untapped potential.

I believe in everything
happening for a reason in life.

People in my country
are impacted by things
that are done unethically.

And that taught me to
value everyone around me
and not take my community for granted.
Now, I'm on the other side doing work

to improve my community and
hopefully the rest of the world.
